people.name: Arthur Engoron
people.description: Judge Arthur Engoron hit Donald Trump with his biggest punishment to date on Friday, in a ruling that fined the former president $355 million for fraudulently inflating the values of his properties.

people.name: Donald Trump
people.description: Donald Trump was fined roughly $438 million over the past four weeks, comprising of a $355 million fine for fraudulently inflating the values of his properties and an $83 million judgment for defaming E. Jean Carroll.

people.name: Letitia James
people.description: New York Attorney General Letitia James had asked Engoron to fine Trump and other defendants $370 million, accusing them of engaging in a long-running fraud scheme of inflating Trump's assets on his financial statements.

people.name: Michael Cohen
people.description: Michael Cohen's trial testimony was acknowledged by Engoron, who ultimately found him credible despite credibility issues.

people.name: Christopher Kise
people.description: Trump attorney Christopher Kise responded to Engoron's ruling stating that the court "ignored the law, ignored the facts."

organizations.name: Trump Organization
organizations.description: Judge Arthur Engoron ruled in favor of the fines without dissolving the Trump Organization but barred Trump from serving as director of a company in New York for three years.

locations.name: New York
locations.description: The location where Donald Trump was barred from serving as director of a company for three years following a fraud ruling.

locations.name: Washington, DC
locations.description: Engoron ruled that Trump and his companies were liable for $126 million in ill-gotten profits from the sale of the Old Post Office in Washington, DC.

locations.name: Bronx
locations.description: Engoron ruled that Trump and his companies were liable for $60 million in profits from the sale of Ferry Point in the Bronx.

dates.description: Judge Arthur Engoron fined Donald Trump $355 million for fraudulently inflating the values of his properties.

statistics.name: Fine amount against Trump and his company
statistics.description: Total fines levied against Donald Trump and his company over the past four weeks, including $355 million for fraudulently inflating property values and $83 million for defamation.

statistics.name: Disgorgement amount fined by Engoron
statistics.description: Judge Arthur Engoron fined Donald Trump $355 million in disgorgement, representing the return of ill-gotten gains for inflating the values of his properties.

statistics.name: Interest saved by fraud
statistics.description: Engoron found that the defendants' fraud saved them about $168 million in interest.

statistics.name: Ill-gotten profits from the sale of the Old Post Office
statistics.description: The judge ruled that Trump and his companies were liable for $126 million in ill-gotten profits from the sale of the Old Post Office in Washington, DC.

statistics.name: Ill-gotten profits from the sale of Ferry Point
statistics.description: The judge ruled that Trump and his companies were liable for $60 million in profits from the sale of Ferry Point in the Bronx.

connections.description: Donald Trump faced an $83 million judgment for defaming E. Jean Carroll, in addition to a $355 million fine for property value inflation.
New York Attorney General Letitia James brought forth the case against Donald Trump, accusing him of a fraud scheme.
Engoron acknowledged Michael Cohen's theatrical trial testimony against Donald Trump and ultimately found him credible.

quotes.quote: Their complete lack of contrition and remorse borders on pathological.
quotes.speaker: Arthur Engoron
quotes.description: Judge Arthur Engoron's remark on Trump and his co-defendants' lack of remorse in his ruling.

quotes.quote: The Court found his testimony credible, based on the relaxed manner in which he testified, the general plausibility of his statements, and, most importantly, the way his testimony was corroborated by other trial evidence.
quotes.speaker: Arthur Engoron
quotes.description: Judge Arthur Engoron on Michael Cohen's credibility as a witness against Donald Trump.

quotes.quote: The court ignored the law, ignored the facts.
quotes.speaker: Christopher Kise
quotes.description: Trump attorney Christopher Kise's statement in response to Engoron's ruling.

events.title: Ruling against Donald Trump
events.description: Judge Arthur Engoron fined Donald Trump $355 million for fraudulent property value inflation, which is part of the total fines of $438 million levied against him over the past four weeks.

people.name: Wayne LaPierre
people.role: Former CEO of the National Rifle Association
people.description: Testified he wasn't in it for the money and defended the expenses as an effort to bolster the NRA's reach and importance.

people.name: Wilson "Woody" Philips
people.role: Former CFO of the National Rifle Association
people.description: Defendant in the NRA's civil corruption trial along with LaPierre and others.

people.name: John Frazer
people.role: General counsel of the National Rifle Association
people.description: Accused alongside LaPierre and Philips of misadministrating charitable money and violating non-profit laws.

people.name: Monica Connell
people.description: Argued in closing arguments that the NRA executives engaged in corruption and should pay back millions to the organization.

people.name: Oliver North
people.description: Testified earlier for the state; his hiring and dismissal by LaPierre used as an example of alleged corruption.

people.name: Kent Correll
people.description: Defended LaPierre during closing arguments, saying he wasn't interested in building a pile of money for himself.

people.name: Letitia James
people.description: Her office is asking the jury to find against LaPierre and others, for the reimbursement and penalties to the NRA.

people.name: Sarah Rodgers
people.description: Stated that the misconduct was concealed from the NRA, and damages are payable to the organization, not the state.

organizations.name: National Rifle Association
organizations.description: Accused of mass corruption in a civil trial; executives allegedly spent millions on personal expenses.

dates.description: Jury began deliberations in the civil corruption trial against the National Rifle Association and its executives.
